results.title: Two Laws
results.brief_description: An innovative film on the Borroloola people’s struggle for the recognition of Aboriginal law. Aborigines actively collaborated with the filmmakers in determining the form of the film which is in four parts. “Police times” is a dramatic re-enactment of white oppression in the 1930’s. “Welfare times” A re-enactment of life under the welfare system of the 1950’s. In “Struggle for our land” Aboriginal attachment to the land is described and the first hearing of the Borroloola land claim is also re-enacted. “Living with two laws” is concerned with the movement back to traditional land and the setting up of cattle out-stations.

In “Struggle for our land” Aboriginal attachment to the land is described and the first hearing of the Borroloola land claim is also re-enacted. “Living with two laws” is concerned with the movement back to traditional land and the setting up of cattle out-stations.

results.title: Dreaming in motion picture
results.creator_credit: Ian RT Colless, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Through music and footage of dance, Ian Colless weaves a tale, of his upbringing as a Gundungurra man, his home in the Blue Mountains and the journey to becoming a dancer. Ian has found a way to combine the various cultures and identities within him through dance, making his body a symbol of reconciliation and giving his people a voice.

results.title: A Christmas story
results.creator_credit: Djuma Dawes, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: After the Australian Government’s 2008 introduction of a new ‘income management’ regime for Northern Territory Aboriginal Australians, many families were unable to celebrate Christmas as usual. Djuma Dawes tells how his mother and other supporters, including Rotary Australia, arranged for the delivery of 16,000 Christmas presents across the Territory, believing that ‘everyone deserves to have a Merry Christmas.’
results.creator_credit_for_label: Djuma Dawes, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Two hours of christmas cartoons
results.creator_credit: Music World and Hughes Leisure Group
results.brief_description: A compilation of cartoons from the forties and fifties which feature classic stories such as ‘Rudolph the red-nosed reindeer’, ‘Santa’s surprise’, ‘Jingle bell foolin’, ‘Christmas circus’ and a host of other titles guaranteed to generate lots of Christmas spirit.

results.title: Two hands [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Gregor Jordan, Marian MacGowan, Meridian Films and CML
results.brief_description: Set in Sydney’s King’s Cross, 19 year old Jimmy (Heath Ledger) finds himself in debt to a local gangster, Pando, played by perennial Australian actor Bryan Brown, when a simple job goes wrong. Jimmy’s life depends on his locating the $10,000 he has lost. As his scheme to replace the cash is played out, two street kids are enjoying a shopping spree with the original loot. The black humour of the film progressively darkens as the story unfolds. Rose Byrne co-stars as country girl, Alex, who becomes involved with Jimmy and his increasingly dire situation.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gregor Jordan, Marian MacGowan, Meridian Films and CML

results.title: [Tony Agapitos: Ninolakis the Poet]
results.brief_description:
This silent film shows an intimate lounge room party and poetry reading by a poet known as Ninolakis.

This film is part of a collection of 16mm films made by Tony Agapitos. The collection offers a glimpse at Greek migrant life in Victoria from the 1950s to the 1970s.

results.title: [Tony Agapitos: Miss Greek Charity Quest]
results.brief_description:
This silent film shows people at the Athenaeum Club in Melbourne celebrating the New Year and finalists of the Miss Greek Charity Quest.

This film is part of a collection of 16mm films made by Tony Agapitos. The collection offers a glimpse at Greek migrant life in Victoria from the 1950s to the 1970s.

results.title: Two hands
results.creator_credit: Gregor Jordan, Marian MacGowan, Meridian Films and CML
results.brief_description: Set in Sydney’s King’s Cross, 19 year old Jimmy (Heath Ledger) finds himself in debt to a local gangster, Pando, played by perennial Australian actor Bryan Brown, when a simple job goes wrong. Jimmy’s life depends on his locating the $10,000 he has lost. As his scheme to replace the cash is played out, two street kids are enjoying a shopping spree with the original loot. The black humour of the film progressively darkens as the story unfolds. Rose Byrne co-stars as country girl, Alex, who becomes involved with Jimmy and his increasingly dire situation.
